Problem:
Consider a continuous system described by the partial differential equation \\(u_t + a(x,t) u_x = 0\\), where \\(a(x,t)\\) is a function describing the velocity at point x and time t. We examine the effect of an integral transform, specifically the Fourier transform \\(\\mathcal{F}(u)(\\xi,t) = \\int_{-\\infty}^{\\infty} e^{-i x \\xi} u(x,t) dx\\).

If an intervention is applied at time \\(t_1\\), modifying the velocity function to a new \\(a'(x,t)\\) for \\(t > t_1\\), will the Fourier transform \\(\\mathcal{F}(u)(\\xi,T)\\) for \\(T > t_1\\) still provide an accurate reflection of the system evolution based solely on the initial velocity function \\(a(x,t)\\)?
Explanation: The intervention changes the velocity profile, directly affecting advection characteristics and thus affecting the Fourier transform's phase shift and amplitude. The Fourier transform at \\(T > t_1\\) will encapsulate effects from both the original and altered velocity profiles, making it dependent on both.
